worked_examples.title: Short Conceptual Questions
worked_examples.problem_statement: A) Unlimited Liability and Risk Management (15 pts) Compare two business structures: Structure 1: Partnership with Unlimited Liability ●​ Three partners each own 33.3% of a consulting firm ●​ Each partner is personally liable for all debts and obligations of the firm ●​ If the firm cannot pay its debts, creditors can pursue partners' personal assets (homes, savings, etc.) Structure 2: Corporation with Limited Liability ●​ Three shareholders each own 33.3% of a consulting corporation ●​ Shareholders' liability is limited to their investment in the firm ●​ If the firm goes bankrupt, shareholders can lose their investment but creditors cannot pursue personal assets Explain: 1. Different incentives to hedge risks: Suppose the firm faces significant malpractice risk (a large lawsuit could bankrupt the firm). ●​ Partnership (unlimited liability): ○​ How much can each partner lose? ○​ Does this create strong incentives to purchase malpractice insurance? ○​ Would partners want to hedge other firm-specific risks (e.g., customer concentration, key personnel risk)? ○​ Why? ●​ Corporation (limited liability): ○​ How much can each shareholder lose? ○​ Does this create the same incentives to hedge firm-specific risks? ○​ What is the maximum downside for a diversified shareholder? 2. Intuition: Explain in general terms: ●​ Why does unlimited liability make owners more risk-averse? ●​ Why does limited liability allow owners to "walk away" from downside risk? ●​ How does this affect the desire to hedge idiosyncratic (diversifiable) risks? 3. Implications: If partnerships have stronger incentives to hedge, what predictions would we make about: ●​ Insurance purchases? ●​ Business practices (conservative vs. aggressive)? ●​ Growth strategies? B) Capital Structure and Required Returns (15 pts) Unlevered Corp currently has no debt (all-equity financed). The company decides to recapitalize: ●​ Issues $200M in debt ●​ Uses the proceeds to repurchase equity Observed changes: ●​ Equity beta increases from 1.0 to 1.4 ●​ Expected return on equity increases from 10% to 13.2% A junior analyst observes: "Since equity holders now require a 13.2% return instead of 10%, the value of the firm must have fallen because we're discounting cash flows at a higher rate." Explain why this reasoning is incorrect: 1. What determines firm value? ●​ Does firm value depend on how it's financed (M&M proposition 1)? ●​ What actually drives firm value? (Expected cash flows from assets, risk of assets) 2. What happens to the weighted average cost of capital (WACC)? Before recapitalization: ●​ WACC = r_E = 10% (since 100% equity) After recapitalization (assume D/V = 40%, E/V = 60%, r_D = 5%, no taxes for simplicity): ●​ WACC = r_D × (D/V) + r_E × (E/V) ●​ WACC = 5% × 0.4 + 13.2% × 0.6 = ? How does WACC change? 3. Explain the intuition: ●​ ●​ ●​ ●​ The required return on equity increases because equity becomes riskier (more leverage) But cheaper debt partially offsets this The overall cost of capital (WACC) may stay constant or even decrease (with taxes) Firm value depends on WACC and asset cash flows, not just r_E 4. With corporate taxes: If we introduce a 25% tax rate, how does the tax shield affect firm value? ●​ Does leverage increase value through tax shields? ●​ But does this have anything to do with the equity required return increasing? Conclusion: Does an increase in leverage and equity required return, by itself, increase or decrease firm value? Explain completely. C) Dividend Smoothing (10 pts) Empirically, firms tend to maintain stable or gradually increasing dividends rather than letting dividends fluctuate with quarterly earnings. Example: ●​ A firm earns $1.00/share in Q1, $0.60/share in Q2, $1.20/share in Q3, $0.80/share in Q4 ●​ Rather than paying dividends equal to earnings each quarter, the firm pays a stable $0.25/share every quarter Provide two reasons why "smoothing" dividends might be valuable: Reason 1 - Signaling: 1.​ What signal does a dividend cut send to the market? ○​ Managers have private information about future prospects ○​ Cutting dividends might signal that management expects earnings will remain low ○​ Market may interpret this negatively 2.​ Why might managers be reluctant to increase dividends temporarily if they can't sustain the increase? ○​ Having to cut later sends a very negative signal ○​ Better to maintain a stable level that's clearly sustainable Reason 2 - Investor Clienteles: 1.​ Who invests in dividend-paying stocks? ○​ Many investors rely on dividends for income (retirees, institutions) ○​ These investors prefer stable, predictable income 2.​ What happens if dividends fluctuate wildly? ○​ Investors who need stable income will avoid the stock ○​ May trade at a discount due to reduced clientele Additional considerations: ●​ Transaction costs: If investors need stable income, fluctuating dividends force them to sell shares to make up shortfalls (costly) ●​ Tax efficiency: Stable dividend policies may allow better tax planning Caveat: In a perfect M&M world, dividend policy is irrelevant. Explain briefly why these considerations represent market frictions that make smoothing potentially valuable despite M&M irrelevance.

Conclusion: Does an increase in leverage and equity required return, by itself, increase or decrease firm value? Explain completely. C) Dividend Smoothing (10 pts) Empirically, firms tend to maintain stable or gradually increasing dividends rather than letting dividends fluctuate with quarterly earnings. Example: ●​ A firm earns $1.00/share in Q1, $0.60/share in Q2, $1.20/share in Q3, $0.80/share in Q4 ●​ Rather than paying dividends equal to earnings each quarter, the firm pays a stable $0.25/share every quarter Provide two reasons why "smoothing" dividends might be valuable: Reason 1 - Signaling: 1.​ What signal does a dividend cut send to the market? ○​ Managers have private information about future prospects ○​ Cutting dividends might signal that management expects earnings will remain low ○​ Market may interpret this negatively 2.​ Why might managers be reluctant to increase dividends temporarily if they can't sustain the increase? ○​ Having to cut later sends a very negative signal ○​ Better to maintain a stable level that's clearly sustainable Reason 2 - Investor Clienteles: 1.​ Who invests in dividend-paying stocks? ○​ Many investors rely on dividends for income (retirees, institutions) ○​ These investors prefer stable, predictable income 2.​ What happens if dividends fluctuate wildly? ○​ Investors who need stable income will avoid the stock ○​ May trade at a discount due to reduced clientele Additional considerations: ●​ Transaction costs: If investors need stable income, fluctuating dividends force them to sell shares to make up shortfalls (costly) ●​ Tax efficiency: Stable dividend policies may allow better tax planning Caveat: In a perfect M&M world, dividend policy is irrelevant. Explain briefly why these considerations represent market frictions that make smoothing potentially valuable despite M&M irrelevance.

worked_examples.title: Short Conceptual Questions
worked_examples.problem_statement: A) Personal Taxes and Capital Structure (15 pts) In the standard Modigliani-Miller analysis with corporate taxes, debt provides a tax shield because interest is tax-deductible while dividends are not. However, when we introduce personal taxes, debt can become less attractive even when the corporate tax rate is positive. Explain completely: How can personal taxes reduce or even eliminate the tax advantage of debt? In your answer, reference: ●​ The tax treatment of interest income vs. equity income at the personal level ●​ The combined effect of corporate and personal taxes ●​ Under what conditions debt might actually be tax-disadvantaged B) Leverage and Equity Beta (15 pts) Consider two firms with identical assets (same business risk). Firm A is all-equity financed, while Firm B uses 40% debt financing. Firm B's equity beta is 1.5, while Firm A's equity beta is 1.0. Explain: Why does Firm B's equity have a higher beta even though both firms have the same underlying asset risk? Walk through: ●​ The relationship between asset beta, debt beta, and equity beta ●​ How leverage magnifies equity risk ●​ Why this relationship holds even if the asset beta stays constant C) Optimal Leverage in Profitable, Stable Firms (10 pts) Classical trade-off theory suggests firms balance the tax benefits of debt against financial distress costs. Consider a highly profitable firm in a stable industry (e.g., consumer staples, utilities) with: ●​ Consistent cash flows ●​ Low business risk ●​ High tax rates Explain: Why might such a firm optimally choose some leverage instead of zero leverage? Reference: ●​ Tax shield benefits ●​ Low probability of distress ●​ The optimal debt level consideration

worked_examples.title: Short Conceptual Questions
worked_examples.problem_statement: A) Economic vs. Financial Distress (15 pts) CycleCorp is a manufacturing firm that produces recreational vehicles. A severe recession hits, causing: ●​ ●​ ●​ ●​ Sales to fall 40% Operating profits to decline sharply Planned capacity expansion to be cancelled Workforce reductions Distinguish between economic distress and financial distress for CycleCorp: 1.​ Define economic distress and provide one specific example from CycleCorp's situation 2.​ Define financial distress and provide one specific example that would constitute financial (not just economic) distress 3.​ Explain: Could CycleCorp experience economic distress without financial distress? Under what conditions? B) Project Discount Rates vs. Company Cost of Capital (15 pts) Consolidated Industries is a diversified conglomerate with an overall asset beta of 0.8. The firm is considering entering a new business line: cloud computing services. Comparable firm analysis reveals: ●​ Pure-play cloud computing companies have equity betas averaging 1.4 ●​ These comparable firms have no debt (all-equity financed) ●​ Risk-free rate: 3% ●​ Market risk premium: 7% Explain: 1.​ Why would it be incorrect to use Consolidated's existing cost of capital (based on β = 0.8) to evaluate the cloud computing project? 2.​ How would you estimate the appropriate discount rate for this project using the comparable firms? Walk through the steps: ○​ What is the asset beta of the comparable firms? ○​ What discount rate should Consolidated use for the cloud project? ○​ Show your calculation 3.​ What error would occur if Consolidated used its company-wide WACC instead? C) Hedging vs. Speculation with Interest Rate Swaps (10 pts) TechVenture Corp has $200 million in floating-rate debt (pays LIBOR + 2%). The CFO believes interest rates will fall over the next two years based on his economic analysis. He proposes entering an interest rate swap where TechVenture: ●​ Pays a fixed rate of 4.5% ●​ Receives LIBOR Analyze this proposal: 1.​ Is this primarily a hedging transaction or speculation? Explain. 2.​ Under what circumstances could this swap actually reduce risk and potentially increase firm value? Consider: ○​ The correlation between TechVenture's business and interest rates ○​ Potential financial distress costs ○​ Management's comparative advantage 3.​ What would be different if TechVenture's cash flows naturally increased when interest rates rose (negative correlation)?

solution.content:
Question 2 – Short Conceptual Questions (40 points)
A) Economic vs. Financial Distress (15 pts)
CycleCorp is a manufacturing firm that produces recreational vehicles. A severe recession hits, causing:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Sales to fall 40%
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Operating profits to decline sharply
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Planned capacity expansion to be cancelled
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Workforce reductions
Distinguish between economic distress and financial distress for CycleCorp:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. Define economic distress and provide one specific example from CycleCorp's situation
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. Define financial distress and provide one specific example that would constitute financial (not just economic) distress
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    3. Explain: Could CycleCorp experience economic distress without financial distress? Under what conditions?
B) Project Discount Rates vs. Company Cost of Capital (15 pts)
Consolidated Industries is a diversified conglomerate with an overall asset beta of 0.8. The firm is considering entering a new business line: cloud computing services.
Comparable firm analysis reveals:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Pure-play cloud computing companies have equity betas averaging 1.4
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * These comparable firms have no debt (all-equity financed)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Risk-free rate: 3%
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Market risk premium: 7%
Explain:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. Why would it be incorrect to use Consolidated's existing cost of capital (based on β = 0.8) to evaluate the cloud computing project?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. How would you estimate the appropriate discount rate for this project using the comparable firms? Walk through the steps:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * What is the asset beta of the comparable firms?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * What discount rate should Consolidated use for the cloud project?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Show your calculation
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    3. What error would occur if Consolidated used its company-wide WACC instead?
C) Hedging vs. Speculation with Interest Rate Swaps (10 pts)
TechVenture Corp has $200 million in floating-rate debt (pays LIBOR + 2%). The CFO believes interest rates will fall over the next two years based on his economic analysis.
He proposes entering an interest rate swap where TechVenture:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Pays a fixed rate of 4.5%
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Receives LIBOR
Analyze this proposal:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    1. Is this primarily a hedging transaction or speculation? Explain.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    2. Under what circumstances could this swap actually reduce risk and potentially increase firm value? Consider:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * The correlation between TechVenture's business and interest rates
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Potential financial distress costs
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * Management's comparative advantage
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    3. What would be different if TechVenture's cash flows naturally increased when interest rates rose (negative correlation)?
________________

worked_examples.title: Short Conceptual Questions
worked_examples.problem_statement: A) WACC and Project Risk Mismatch (15 pts) TechConglomerate Inc. has a company-wide WACC of 9%, based on its average business risk (asset beta = 1.0). The company is considering two projects: Project A: Low-risk utility infrastructure ●​ Comparable firms in this sector have asset betas of 0.4 ●​ Project NPV using 9% discount rate: -$5 million Project B: High-risk biotech venture ●​ Comparable firms in this sector have asset betas of 1.8 ●​ Project NPV using 9% discount rate: +$10 million Explain: 1.​ What error does TechConglomerate make by using its company-wide WACC for both projects? 2.​ For each project, would using a risk-adjusted discount rate (rather than the 9% WACC) make the project more or less attractive? Why? 3.​ What real-world consequences could result from using the wrong discount rate? Specifically, how might this lead to: ○​ Rejecting good projects? ○​ Accepting bad projects? ○​ Changing the firm's risk profile over time? B) Wealth Transfers in Equity Issuance (15 pts) Consider an all-equity firm that issues new shares to finance a positive-NPV project. Suppose: ●​ The equity issue is priced fairly (zero NPV for new investors) ●​ The project has NPV = $20 million ●​ The firm has existing senior claims (e.g., pension obligations, preferred stock) Explain with a numerical example: 1.​ How can the equity issue be zero-NPV for new investors yet still transfer wealth away from old shareholders? 2.​ Where does the project's $20 million NPV go if not to the old shareholders? 3.​ Under what conditions would old shareholders still want to proceed with the equity-financed project? Hint: Consider how the project's value is distributed among all claimants, not just equity. C) Why Not 100% Debt Financing? (10 pts) If interest is tax-deductible and provides a tax shield, why don't all firms with positive-NPV projects use 100% debt financing? Provide at least three distinct reasons, referencing: ●​ ●​ ●​ ●​ ●​ Financial distress costs Debt overhang and underinvestment Loss of financial flexibility Contracting and agency costs Other real-world considerations Question 3 – Inside vs. Outside Equity Financing (80 points) Riverside Development is a real estate firm owned 100% by three inside investors (founders). The firm currently has no debt and no outside shareholders. Riverside has identified a commercial property development opportunity. Current Situation: ●​ 100% insider ownership ●​ No debt ●​ Founders have sufficient personal wealth to fund the project Future Asset Values (one year from today, in millions): State Probability Existing Assets Project Value Downtur n 25% $120 $50 Stable 50% $180 $90 Growth 25% $240 $140 Project Details: ●​ Required investment today: $80 million ●​ Discount rate: 10% for all cashflows A) Calculate project NPV (15 pts) Compute the NPV of the development project in an M&M world (ignoring financing). Show: 1.​ Expected value of project one year from now 2.​ Present value today 3.​ NPV (PV minus $80 million investment) Is this a value-creating project? B) Inside equity financing (20 pts) Scenario 1: The three founders contribute $80 million from their personal wealth (proportional to their existing ownership stakes). Calculate: 1.​ Value of Riverside before the project 2.​ Value of Riverside after the project (with inside financing) 3.​ Change in insider wealth Show that insiders capture the full NPV when they finance the project themselves. C) Outside equity financing (20 pts) Scenario 2: The founders issue $80 million in new common equity to outside investors. Calculate: 1.​ What fraction k of the post-investment firm do outsiders receive for their $80 million? 2.​ Value of insiders' stake after the outside equity issue 3.​ Change in insider wealth compared to not doing the project D) Compare financing methods (15 pts) Compare insider wealth under the two financing scenarios: Scenario No project Insider Wealth Change from Status Quo Baseline Inside equity Outside equity Which financing method do insiders prefer? Why? E) Explain the underinvestment problem (10 pts) Even though the project has positive NPV, might insiders reject it if they must use outside equity financing? Explain: 1.​ Under what conditions would insiders reject a positive-NPV project? 2.​ Why does this represent a market failure? 3.​ What is this problem called in corporate finance? 4.​ How could debt financing potentially solve this problem? Question 4 – Distress Costs and Payoff Distribution (60 points) Omega Transport operates a fleet of commercial trucks. The company has the following capital structure: Secured Bank Loan: ●​ Face value: $150 million ●​ Collateralized by the truck fleet ●​ Senior to all other claims Unsecured Bond: ●​ Face value: $100 million ●​ Junior to secured debt Common Equity: ●​ Residual claimant All debt matures simultaneously in 2 years. Fire-Sale Discount: If Omega is sold in financial distress, assets realize only 70% of their going-concern value due to: ●​ Forced liquidation timing ●​ Adverse selection (buyers assume the worst) ●​ Thin market for specialized trucking assets A) Illustrate fire-sale impact on claims (20 pts) Suppose Omega's going-concern asset value at maturity would be $280 million, but financial distress forces a sale. Calculate the payoff to each claimant under two scenarios: Scenario 1: No distress (going-concern value = $280M) Claimant Secured bank loan Unsecured bond Payof f Common equity Total $280 M Scenario 2: Distress sale (fire-sale value = 0.70 × $280M = $196M) Claimant Payof f Secured bank loan Unsecured bond Common equity Total $196 M Who bears the $84 million fire-sale cost? B) Ex-ante burden of distress costs (20 pts) Before maturity, when the capital structure is initially created, explain: 1.​ Why are distress costs borne primarily by equity ex-ante, even though in some states other claimants also suffer losses? 2.​ How do debt holders protect themselves from distress costs when they initially lend? 3.​ Use the concept of pricing in expected losses to explain why equity holders effectively bear the cost upfront. C) Link to optimal leverage (20 pts) Using the insights from parts A and B, explain how distress costs affect optimal leverage decisions: 1.​ Why don't firms lever up to extreme levels (e.g., 95% debt)? 2.​ How do the following factors affect optimal leverage: ○​ Probability of distress: What if the business is more volatile? ○​ Magnitude of fire-sale discount: What if assets are more liquid? ○​ Tax benefits: How do these trade off against distress costs? 3.​ Why might firms in different industries have very different leverage ratios? Provide two specific industry examples. MOCK FINAL 6

solution.content:
Question 2 – Short Conceptual Questions (40 points)
A) WACC and Project Risk Mismatch (15 pts)
TechConglomerate Inc. has a company-wide WACC of 9%, based on its average business risk (asset beta = 1.0). The company is considering two projects:
Project A: Low-risk utility infrastructure
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Comparable firms in this sector have asset betas of 0.4
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project NPV using 9% discount rate: -$5 million
Project B: High-risk biotech venture
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Comparable firms in this sector have asset betas of 1.8
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project NPV using 9% discount rate: +$10 million
Explain:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. What error does TechConglomerate make by using its company-wide WACC for both projects?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. For each project, would using a risk-adjusted discount rate (rather than the 9% WACC) make the project more or less attractive? Why?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. What real-world consequences could result from using the wrong discount rate? Specifically, how might this lead to:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Rejecting good projects?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Accepting bad projects?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Changing the firm's risk profile over time?
        The Error: TechConglomerate is incorrectly assuming all projects have the same systematic risk as the firm's average (βA=1.0). The WACC is only appropriate as a hurdle rate for projects that mirror the firm’s existing risk profile.
Impact on Attractiveness:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project A (Low Risk, β=0.4): The 9% WACC is too high. A lower, risk-adjusted discount rate should be used. Using the correct rate would increase the NPV, making it more attractive.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project B (High Risk, β=1.8): The 9% WACC is too low. A higher, risk-adjusted discount rate should be used. Using the correct rate would decrease the NPV, making it less attractive.
Real-world consequences:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Rejecting good projects: The firm will systematically underinvest in safe, positive-NPV projects (like A) because the hurdle rate is set too high.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Accepting bad projects: The firm will systematically overinvest in risky, potentially negative-NPV projects (like B) because the hurdle rate is set too low.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Changing the firm's risk profile: Over time, the firm will accumulate high-risk assets and shed low-risk assets, causing the firm’s overall risk (asset beta) to increase.
B) Wealth Transfers in Equity Issuance (15 pts)
Consider an all-equity firm that issues new shares to finance a positive-NPV project. Suppose:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * The equity issue is priced fairly (zero NPV for new investors)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * The project has NPV = $20 million
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * The firm has existing senior claims (e.g., pension obligations, preferred stock)
Explain with a numerical example:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. How can the equity issue be zero-NPV for new investors yet still transfer wealth away from old shareholders?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Where does the project's $20 million NPV go if not to the old shareholders?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Under what conditions would old shareholders still want to proceed with the equity-financed project?
Hint: Consider how the project's value is distributed among all claimants, not just equity.
This scenario describes the Debt Overhang problem (applied here to senior claims like pensions or preferred stock).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * How wealth is transferred: When risky senior claims exist, a new project—even if positive NPV—might primarily benefit those senior claimants by increasing the firm's solvency and making their claims safer (de-risking). Equity holders provide the funding but only capture the residual value.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Numerical Example (Illustrative): Firm V=$100M. Senior claims Face=$80M, Market Value=$60M (due to risk). Equity=$40M. Project NPV=$20M. Firm value increases to $120M. If the project significantly reduces firm risk, the value of senior claims might increase from $60M to $75M. New Equity Value = $120M - $75M = $45M.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Where the NPV goes: Of the $20M NPV, $15M ($75M-$60M) is captured by the Senior Claimants, and $5M ($45M-$40M) is captured by equity (old + new).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Zero-NPV for new investors, loss for old: New investors buy their share of the $45M equity at a fair price (Zero-NPV). Old shareholders only see a $5M gain, less than the full NPV.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Conditions to proceed: Old shareholders only proceed if the share of the NPV they capture is positive and sufficient. If the overhang is severe, they may reject the project.
C) Why Not 100% Debt Financing? (10 pts)
If interest is tax-deductible and provides a tax shield, why don't all firms with positive-NPV projects use 100% debt financing?
Provide at least three distinct reasons, referencing:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Financial distress costs
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Debt overhang and underinvestment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Loss of financial flexibility
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Contracting and agency costs
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Other real-world considerations
Despite the tax advantages of debt, firms limit leverage due to several critical frictions:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Financial Distress Costs: High leverage increases the probability of bankruptcy, which incurs direct costs (legal fees) and significant indirect costs (lost customers, supplier issues, fire sales of assets). These expected costs offset the tax benefits.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Agency Costs of Debt (Debt Overhang and Risk-Shifting): Highly levered firms may suffer from underinvestment (Debt Overhang) or take excessive risks (Risk-Shifting) to benefit equity holders at the expense of debt holders.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Loss of Financial Flexibility: Extreme leverage consumes all debt capacity, leaving the firm unable to raise funds during downturns or to finance unexpected opportunities (financial slack).
________________

The company has the following capital structure: Secured Bank Loan: ●​ Face value: $150 million ●​ Collateralized by the truck fleet ●​ Senior to all other claims Unsecured Bond: ●​ Face value: $100 million ●​ Junior to secured debt Common Equity: ●​ Residual claimant All debt matures simultaneously in 2 years. Calculate the payoff to each claimant under two scenarios: Scenario 1: No distress (going-concern value = $280M) Claimant Secured bank loan Unsecured bond Payof f Common equity Total $280 M Scenario 2: Distress sale (fire-sale value = 0.70 × $280M = $196M) Claimant Payof f Secured bank loan Unsecured bond Common equity Total $196 M Who bears the $84 million fire-sale cost? B) Ex-ante burden of distress costs (20 pts) Before maturity, when the capital structure is initially created, explain: 1.​ Why are distress costs borne primarily by equity ex-ante, even though in some states other claimants also suffer losses? 2.​ How do debt holders protect themselves from distress costs when they initially lend? 3.​ Use the concept of pricing in expected losses to explain why equity holders effectively bear the cost upfront. C) Link to optimal leverage (20 pts) Using the insights from parts A and B, explain how distress costs affect optimal leverage decisions: 1.​ Why don't firms lever up to extreme levels (e.g., 95% debt)? 2.​ How do the following factors affect optimal leverage: ○​ Probability of distress: What if the business is more volatile? ○​ Magnitude of fire-sale discount: What if assets are more liquid? ○​ Tax benefits: How do these trade off against distress costs? 3.​ Why might firms in different industries have very different leverage ratios? Provide two specific industry examples. MOCK FINAL 6

worked_examples.problem_statement: A) Payout Policy in High-Growth Firms (15 pts) NexGen Biotech is a high-growth company with: ●​ Numerous positive-NPV projects in its pipeline ●​ Limited current cash generation ●​ Significant R&D investment needs However, activist investors are pressuring NexGen to initiate a regular dividend, arguing that "all successful companies pay dividends." Analyze this situation: 1.​ What are the arguments against paying dividends for a firm like NexGen? Consider: ○​ Investment opportunities ○​ Financing costs ○​ Tax efficiency 2.​ What might explain the investors' pressure for dividends? Consider: ○​ Agency conflicts ○​ Signaling ○​ Clientele preferences 3.​ What would you recommend? Is there a middle ground? B) P/CF Multiples Across Firms (15 pts) Two firms in the same industry have very different Price-to-Cash-Flow multiples: ●​ CompanyA: P/CF = 12× ●​ Company B: P/CF = 24× Both firms have positive cash flows and similar current profitability. Explain how differences in growth vs. risk can justify Company B trading at twice Company A's multiple: 1.​ Growth perspective: How would higher expected future growth justify a higher P/CF? 2.​ Risk perspective: How would lower systematic risk (beta) justify a higher P/CF? 3.​ Provide a numerical example: Assume both firms have current CF = $100M. Using a simple valuation formula, show how different assumptions about growth and/or discount rates could yield the observed multiples. C) Hedging and Underinvestment (10 pts) ChemCorp is near financial distress with debt coming due in one year. The company has valuable growth opportunities but may not have sufficient cash to invest if commodity prices fall. Explain how hedging commodity price risk with derivatives could: 1.​ Reduce the underinvestment problem 2.​ Increase firm value even if hedging doesn't change expected cashflows 3.​ Benefit equity holders despite protecting debtholders Reference the relationship between: ●​ Cash flow volatility ●​ Financial distress ●​ Investment capacity

solution.content:
Question 2 – Short Conceptual Questions (40 points)
A) WACC and Project Risk Mismatch (15 pts)
TechConglomerate Inc. has a company-wide WACC of 9%, based on its average business risk (asset beta = 1.0). The company is considering two projects:
Project A: Low-risk utility infrastructure
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Comparable firms in this sector have asset betas of 0.4
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project NPV using 9% discount rate: -$5 million
Project B: High-risk biotech venture
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Comparable firms in this sector have asset betas of 1.8
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project NPV using 9% discount rate: +$10 million
Explain:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. What error does TechConglomerate make by using its company-wide WACC for both projects?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. For each project, would using a risk-adjusted discount rate (rather than the 9% WACC) make the project more or less attractive? Why?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. What real-world consequences could result from using the wrong discount rate? Specifically, how might this lead to:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Rejecting good projects?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Accepting bad projects?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Changing the firm's risk profile over time?
        The Error: TechConglomerate is incorrectly assuming all projects have the same systematic risk as the firm's average (βA=1.0). The WACC is only appropriate as a hurdle rate for projects that mirror the firm’s existing risk profile.
Impact on Attractiveness:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project A (Low Risk, β=0.4): The 9% WACC is too high. A lower, risk-adjusted discount rate should be used. Using the correct rate would increase the NPV, making it more attractive.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Project B (High Risk, β=1.8): The 9% WACC is too low. A higher, risk-adjusted discount rate should be used. Using the correct rate would decrease the NPV, making it less attractive.
Real-world consequences:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Rejecting good projects: The firm will systematically underinvest in safe, positive-NPV projects (like A) because the hurdle rate is set too high.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Accepting bad projects: The firm will systematically overinvest in risky, potentially negative-NPV projects (like B) because the hurdle rate is set too low.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Changing the firm's risk profile: Over time, the firm will accumulate high-risk assets and shed low-risk assets, causing the firm’s overall risk (asset beta) to increase.
B) Wealth Transfers in Equity Issuance (15 pts)
Consider an all-equity firm that issues new shares to finance a positive-NPV project. Suppose:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * The equity issue is priced fairly (zero NPV for new investors)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * The project has NPV = $20 million
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * The firm has existing senior claims (e.g., pension obligations, preferred stock)
Explain with a numerical example:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. How can the equity issue be zero-NPV for new investors yet still transfer wealth away from old shareholders?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Where does the project's $20 million NPV go if not to the old shareholders?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Under what conditions would old shareholders still want to proceed with the equity-financed project?
Hint: Consider how the project's value is distributed among all claimants, not just equity.
This scenario describes the Debt Overhang problem (applied here to senior claims like pensions or preferred stock).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * How wealth is transferred: When risky senior claims exist, a new project—even if positive NPV—might primarily benefit those senior claimants by increasing the firm's solvency and making their claims safer (de-risking). Equity holders provide the funding but only capture the residual value.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Numerical Example (Illustrative): Firm V=$100M. Senior claims Face=$80M, Market Value=$60M (due to risk). Equity=$40M. Project NPV=$20M. Firm value increases to $120M. If the project significantly reduces firm risk, the value of senior claims might increase from $60M to $75M. New Equity Value = $120M - $75M = $45M.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Where the NPV goes: Of the $20M NPV, $15M ($75M-$60M) is captured by the Senior Claimants, and $5M ($45M-$40M) is captured by equity (old + new).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Zero-NPV for new investors, loss for old: New investors buy their share of the $45M equity at a fair price (Zero-NPV). Old shareholders only see a $5M gain, less than the full NPV.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Conditions to proceed: Old shareholders only proceed if the share of the NPV they capture is positive and sufficient. If the overhang is severe, they may reject the project.
C) Why Not 100% Debt Financing? (10 pts)
If interest is tax-deductible and provides a tax shield, why don't all firms with positive-NPV projects use 100% debt financing?
Provide at least three distinct reasons, referencing:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Financial distress costs
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Debt overhang and underinvestment
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Loss of financial flexibility
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Contracting and agency costs
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Other real-world considerations
Despite the tax advantages of debt, firms limit leverage due to several critical frictions:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Financial Distress Costs: High leverage increases the probability of bankruptcy, which incurs direct costs (legal fees) and significant indirect costs (lost customers, supplier issues, fire sales of assets). These expected costs offset the tax benefits.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Agency Costs of Debt (Debt Overhang and Risk-Shifting): Highly levered firms may suffer from underinvestment (Debt Overhang) or take excessive risks (Risk-Shifting) to benefit equity holders at the expense of debt holders.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Loss of Financial Flexibility: Extreme leverage consumes all debt capacity, leaving the firm unable to raise funds during downturns or to finance unexpected opportunities (financial slack).
________________

Analyze this situation: 1.​ What are the arguments against paying dividends for a firm like NexGen? Consider: ○​ Investment opportunities ○​ Financing costs ○​ Tax efficiency 2.​ What might explain the investors' pressure for dividends? Consider: ○​ Agency conflicts ○​ Signaling ○​ Clientele preferences 3.​ What would you recommend? Is there a middle ground? Explain how differences in growth vs. risk can justify Company B trading at twice Company A's multiple: 1.​ Growth perspective: How would higher expected future growth justify a higher P/CF? 2.​ Risk perspective: How would lower systematic risk (beta) justify a higher P/CF? 3.​ Provide a numerical example: Assume both firms have current CF = $100M. worked_examples.title: Option Perspective on Leverage
worked_examples.problem_statement: This question explores how equity's option-like properties change with leverage levels. Background: ●​ Equity can be viewed as a call option on firm assets ●​ Debt can be viewed as risk-free bonds minus a put option Consider three firms with identical assets (value = $500M, volatility = 30%) but different leverage: ●​ Firm L (Low Leverage): Debt face value = $100M ●​ Firm M (Medium Leverage): Debt face value = $300M ●​ Firm H (High Leverage): Debt face value = $450M All debt matures in 3 years. A) Explain option nature with low leverage (15 pts) For Firm L (debt = $100M, assets = $500M): 1.​ Describe equity as a call option: ○​ What is the strike price? ○​ What is the underlying asset? ○​ When is the option exercised? 2.​ Is this option deep in-the-money, at-the-money, or out-of-the-money? 3.​ How does equity behave? ○​ Does it move nearly 1:1 with assets (high delta)? ○​ Is it highly sensitive to volatility (high vega)? Explain why low leverage makes equity behave more like owning the underlying assets. B) Explain option nature with high leverage (15 pts) For Firm H (debt = $450M, assets = $500M): 1.​ Describe equity as a call option: ○​ What is the strike price? ○​ What is the underlying asset? 2.​ Is this option deep in-the-money, at-the-money, or out-of-the-money? 3.​ How does equity behave differently from Firm L? ○​ Sensitivity to asset value changes (delta) ○​ Sensitivity to volatility (vega) Explain why high leverage makes equity behave more option-like. C) Reactions to risk increases (20 pts) Suppose each firm has an opportunity to undertake a risky project that: ●​ Increases asset volatility from 30% to 50% ●​ Has zero NPV (doesn't change expected asset value) Analyze which firm's equity holders would most favor this project: 1.​ Firm L (low leverage): Would equity holders favor increasing volatility? Why or why not? 2.​ Firm M (medium leverage): How does the answer differ from Firm L? 3.​ Firm H (high leverage): How do these equity holders view volatility increases? Explain using option pricing intuition: ●​ How does volatility affect call option values? ●​ How does moneyness (in/at/out-of-the-money) affect vega? D) Implications for corporate governance (10 pts) Based on your analysis: 1.​ Why might high leverage lead to excessive risk-taking by equity holders? 2.​ How could debt covenants address this problem? 3.​ What types of covenant restrictions would be most valuable? Provide three specific examples (e.g., restrictions on dividends, asset sales, additional borrowing, etc.) MOCK FINAL 8

solution.content:
Question 4 – Distress Costs and Payoff Distribution (60 points)
Omega Transport operates a fleet of commercial trucks. The company has the following capital structure:
Secured Bank Loan:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Face value: $150 million
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Collateralized by the truck fleet
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Senior to all other claims
Unsecured Bond:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Face value: $100 million
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Junior to secured debt
Common Equity:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Residual claimant
All debt matures simultaneously in 2 years.
Fire-Sale Discount: If Omega is sold in financial distress, assets realize only 70% of their going-concern value due to:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Forced liquidation timing
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Adverse selection (buyers assume the worst)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Thin market for specialized trucking assets
A) Illustrate fire-sale impact on claims (20 pts)
Suppose Omega's going-concern asset value at maturity would be $280 million, but financial distress forces a sale.
Calculate the payoff to each claimant under two scenarios:
Scenario 1: No distress (going-concern value = $280M)
Claimant
	Payoff
	Secured bank loan
	

	Unsecured bond
	

	Common equity
	

	Total
	$280M
	Scenario 2: Distress sale (fire-sale value = 0.70 × $280M = $196M)
Claimant
	Payoff
	Secured bank loan
	

	Unsecured bond
	

	Common equity
	

	Total
	$196M
	Who bears the $84 million fire-sale cost?
Scenario 1: No distress (Going-concern value = $280M)
Claimant
	Payoff
	Notes
	Secured bank loan
	$150M
	Paid in full
	Unsecured bond
	$100M
	Paid in full
	Common equity
	$30M
	$280M - $250M
	Total
	$280M
	

	

Scenario 2: Distress sale (Fire-sale value = 0.70 × $280M = $196M) Assets are liquidated for $196M. Absolute Priority Rule (APR) is followed.
Claimant
	Payoff
	Notes
	Secured bank loan
	$150M
	Paid first
	Unsecured bond
	$46M
	$196M - $150M
	Common equity
	$0M
	Residual is zero
	Total
	$196M
	

	Who bears the $84 million fire-sale cost? The junior claimants bear the cost. Equity holders lose $30M (their entire claim). Unsecured bondholders lose $54M ($100M - $46M). Total loss = $84M.
B) Ex-ante burden of distress costs (20 pts)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * C) Link to optimal leverage (20 pts)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * 

B) Ex-ante burden of distress costs (20 pts)
Before maturity, when the capital structure is initially created, explain:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Why are distress costs borne primarily by equity ex-ante, even though in some states other claimants also suffer losses?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. How do debt holders protect themselves from distress costs when they initially lend?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Use the concept of pricing in expected losses to explain why equity holders effectively bear the cost upfront.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       4. Why equity bears the cost ex-ante: Although debtholders suffer the losses in the actual event of distress, they anticipate this risk when they initially lend.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       5. How debt holders protect themselves: Lenders demand a higher promised interest rate (credit spread) or a lower purchase price for the debt to compensate for the expected losses in distress (including fire-sale discounts).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       6. Pricing in expected losses: By pricing this risk into the debt contract, the higher financing cost reduces the firm's value today. As equity holders are the residual claimants, this reduction in firm value (due to the anticipated distress costs) is borne by the equity holders ex-ante (upfront).


C) Link to optimal leverage (20 pts)
Using the insights from parts A and B, explain how distress costs affect optimal leverage decisions:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Why don't firms lever up to extreme levels (e.g., 95% debt)?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. How do the following factors affect optimal leverage:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Probability of distress: What if the business is more volatile?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Magnitude of fire-sale discount: What if assets are more liquid?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Tax benefits: How do these trade off against distress costs?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Why might firms in different industries have very different leverage ratios? Provide two specific industry examples.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Why not extreme leverage? According to the Trade-Off Theory, firms balance tax benefits against expected distress costs. At extreme leverage, the expected costs of distress (Probability × Magnitude) rise sharply and eventually outweigh the marginal tax benefits of debt.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Factors affecting optimal leverage:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Probability of distress (Volatility): If the business is more volatile, the probability of distress is higher, leading to lower optimal leverage.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Magnitude of fire-sale discount (Liquidity): If assets are illiquid (high discount, like specialized trucks), distress is costlier, leading to lower optimal leverage.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Tax benefits: Higher tax rates increase the value of the tax shield, pushing optimal leverage higher.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Industry examples:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * High Leverage: Real Estate or Utilities. They possess tangible, relatively liquid assets (lower fire-sale costs) and stable revenues.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Low Leverage: Technology or Pharmaceutical firms. They have high volatility and intangible assets (R&D, patents) that lose significant value in distress (high expected distress costs).
________________

worked_examples.title: Short Conceptual Questions
worked_examples.problem_statement: A) Using Historical Returns vs. CAPM (15 pts) An analyst is evaluating a project and debates between two approaches: Approach 1: Use the historical average return on similar companies (e.g., companies averaged 15% returns over the past 10 years) Approach 2: Use CAPM with current risk-free rate and beta estimates Explain: 1.​ Why might using historical average returns be misleading for project selection? Consider: ●​ Survivorship bias ●​ Time-varying risk premiums ●​ Ex-post vs. ex-ante returns ●​ Sample period selection 2.​ Why is CAPM-based approach generally preferred? 3.​ What are the limitations of the CAPM approach? B) Share Repurchases Above Intrinsic Value (15 pts) TechGrowth's management believes the stock is undervalued at $50 per share, with intrinsic value of $70. However, activist investors pressure management to repurchase shares at the current market price of $50. Later, it turns out management was wrong—the stock was actually overvalued. The true intrinsic value was only $40 per share. Analyze: 1.​ How does repurchasing at $50 (when intrinsic value is $40) affect shareholders who: ○​ Sell their shares in the repurchase? ○​ Retain their shares? 2.​ Provide a numerical example with: ○​ Firm value = $400M (true) ○​ 10M shares outstanding ○​ Firm repurchases 2M shares at $50/share Calculate value per share for remaining shareholders before and after the repurchase. 3.​ What does this illustrate about the importance of price in repurchases? C) Interest Rate Changes and Firm Value (10 pts) Suppose the risk-free rate increases from 3% to 4%, but: ●​ The firm's beta stays the same ●​ The market risk premium stays the same ●​ The firm's expected cash flows don't change Explain: 1.​ Why would the firm's value still decrease? 2.​ Walk through the mechanism: ○​ How does the discount rate change? ○​ How does this affect PV of cash flows? 3.​ Give a specific numerical example using the Gordon Growth Model: V = CF / (r - g) Show how a 1% increase in r affects value.
