solution.content:
Question 1 – Staggered Debt Maturities (60 points)
Fortress Corp has existing debt and plans to add a new tranche with different maturity:
Existing Debt (Tranche A):
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Face value: $200M
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Maturity: 3 years
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Coupon: 5%
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Issued 2 years ago; 3 years remaining
New Debt (Tranche B):
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Face value: $300M
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Maturity: 7 years
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Coupon: 6.5%
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Issued today
Assumptions:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Corporate tax rate: 25%
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Both tranches are bullet bonds (no amortization)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Cost of debt: 6% for 3-year, 6.5% for 7-year
A) Calculate combined tax shield NPV (20 pts)
Compute the present value of tax shields from both tranches:
Tranche A (3 years remaining):
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Annual tax shield
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * PV using 6% discount rate
Tranche B (7 years):
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Annual tax shield
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * PV using 6.5% discount rate
Total tax shield value
B) Maturity structure and refinancing risk (15 pts)
Explain:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. What is "refinancing risk"?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. How does the staggered maturity structure (3-year and 7-year) affect refinancing risk compared to:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * All debt due in 3 years?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * All debt due in 7 years?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Draw a timeline showing when each tranche comes due. What refinancing decisions will Fortress face?
C) Maturity structure and distress risk (15 pts)
Analyze:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Short-maturity debt (3-year):
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Advantages for debt holders?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * How does it affect distress risk?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Agency cost considerations?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Long-maturity debt (7-year):
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Advantages for equity holders?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * How does it affect financial flexibility?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Staggered combination:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Benefits?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Optimal maturity structure considerations?
D) Maturity choice and firm characteristics (10 pts)
Different firms choose different maturity structures. Explain what type of firm would prefer:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Shorter maturities:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Firm characteristics?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Give two specific examples
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Longer maturities:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Firm characteristics?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Give two specific examples
Consider: growth opportunities, asset tangibility, information asymmetry, etc.
________________

worked_examples.problem_intro: Fortress Corp has existing debt and plans to add a new tranche with different maturity: Existing Debt (Tranche A): ●​ ●​ ●​ ●​ Face value: $200M Maturity: 3 years Coupon: 5% Issued 2 years ago; 3 years remaining New Debt (Tranche B): ●​ ●​ ●​ ●​ Face value: $300M Maturity: 7 years Coupon: 6.5% Issued today Assumptions: ●​ Corporate tax rate: 25% ●​ Both tranches are bullet bonds (no amortization) ●​ Cost of debt: 6% for 3-year, 6.5% for 7-year A) Calculate combined tax shield NPV (20 pts) Compute the present value of tax shields from both tranches: Tranche A (3 years remaining): ●​ Annual tax shield ●​ PV using 6% discount rate Tranche B (7 years): ●​ Annual tax shield ●​ PV using 6.5% discount rate Total tax shield value B) Maturity structure and refinancing risk (15 pts) Explain: 1.​ What is "refinancing risk"? 2.​ How does the staggered maturity structure (3-year and 7-year) affect refinancing risk compared to: ○​ All debt due in 3 years? ○​ All debt due in 7 years? 3.​ Draw a timeline showing when each tranche comes due. What refinancing decisions will Fortress face? C) Maturity structure and distress risk (15 pts) Analyze: 1.​ Short-maturity debt (3-year): ○​ Advantages for debt holders? ○​ How does it affect distress risk? ○​ Agency cost considerations? 2.​ Long-maturity debt (7-year): ○​ Advantages for equity holders? ○​ How does it affect financial flexibility? 3.​ Staggered combination: ○​ Benefits? ○​ Optimal maturity structure considerations? D) Maturity choice and firm characteristics (10 pts) Different firms choose different maturity structures. Explain what type of firm would prefer: 1.​ Shorter maturities: ○​ Firm characteristics? ○​ Give two specific examples 2.​ Longer maturities: ○​ Firm characteristics? ○​ Give two specific examples Consider: growth opportunities, asset tangibility, information asymmetry, etc.

worked_examples.title: Short Conceptual Questions
worked_examples.problem_statement: A) Positive Alpha and Market Efficiency (15 pts) TechGrowth Inc. is a publicly traded technology company. An analyst runs a CAPM regression on the stock's historical returns and estimates: ●​ Beta = 1.1 ●​ Risk-free rate = 4% ●​ Market risk premium = 6% CAPM prediction: Expected return = 4% + 1.1 × 6% = 10.6% However, TechGrowth's long-run realized average return has been 13.6%, implying an alpha of +3.0%. Answer the following: 1.​ What does positive alpha mean in CAPM terms? ○​ Define alpha formally ○​ Explain what it means for a stock to deliver returns above its CAPM prediction 2.​ Interpretation 1 - True Mispricing: If markets are inefficient, what does this positive alpha suggest? ○​ Is the stock undervalued or overvalued? ○​ What trading strategy would exploit this? ○​ Why might the mispricing persist? 3.​ Interpretation 2 - Measurement Issues: If markets are efficient, what might explain the apparent alpha? ○​ Sampling error / luck over the estimation period? ○​ Risk factors not captured by the single-factor CAPM (e.g., size, value, momentum)? ○​ Errors in measuring beta? Discuss: How should a rational investor interpret this positive alpha? What additional analysis would help distinguish between these interpretations? B) Debt vs. Equity Financing Under Trade-Off Theory (15 pts) Reliable Industries has a strong balance sheet, stable cash flows, and very low current leverage (D/E = 0.1). The company has identified a positive-NPV expansion project requiring $100 million in financing. Financing options: ●​ All equity: Issue $100M in new common stock ●​ All debt: Issue $100M in bonds ●​ Mixed: Some combination Under trade-off theory, analyze the financing decision: Part 1 - Why some debt might be preferred to all equity: 1.​ What is the tax advantage of debt? ○​ If the corporate tax rate is 25% and the debt coupon rate is 6%, calculate the annual tax shield from $100M of debt ○​ How does this tax shield benefit shareholders? 2.​ Why is the expected cost of financial distress likely low for Reliable Industries? ○​ Current low leverage ○​ Stable cash flows ○​ Strong balance sheet 3.​ Conclusion: Why does trade-off theory suggest that some debt is optimal? Part 2 - Why all debt could be suboptimal: 1.​ What happens to distress costs as leverage increases? ○​ Probability of distress ○​ Expected magnitude of distress costs 2.​ At some leverage level, what relationship holds at the optimum? ○​ Marginal benefit of tax shields ○​ Marginal cost of expected distress 3.​ Conclusion: Why might 100% debt financing exceed the optimal leverage ratio? Overall answer: Explain why the trade-off theory predicts an interior optimum (some debt, but not all debt). C) Fixed vs. Floating Rate Debt (10 pts) Companies can choose between: ●​ Fixed-rate debt: Interest rate locked in (e.g., 6% for 5 years) ●​ Floating-rate debt: Interest rate adjusts with market rates (e.g., LIBOR + 2%) Scenario 1 - Highly cyclical firm (e.g., automotive manufacturer): This firm's cash flows are: ●​ High during economic booms ●​ Low during recessions Interest rates tend to be: ●​ High during booms (Fed tightens) ●​ Low during recessions (Fed eases) Explain: 1.​ Why might this firm prefer fixed-rate debt? ○​ How does floating-rate debt create additional risk? ○​ When would interest payments be highest? ○​ When would cash flows be lowest? ○​ Why does this correlation increase distress risk? Scenario 2 - Very stable firm (e.g., regulated utility): This firm has: ●​ Predictable cash flows ●​ Low correlation with economic cycles ●​ Minimal distress risk Explain: 1.​ Why might this firm be more willing to use floating-rate debt? ○​ Is the mismatch between rates and cash flows a major concern? ○​ What are potential benefits of floating-rate debt (e.g., typically lower initial rates, flexibility)? Conclude: How should the relationship between a firm's cash flows and interest rate cycles influence the fixed vs. floating decision? Question 3 – Multi-State Project and All-Debt Financing (80 points) Zen Transport operates a regional logistics network and is financed entirely with equity. The company has 8 million shares outstanding. One year from today, the value of Zen's existing assets depends on economic conditions: State Probability Asset Value Weak Economy 40% $160 million Strong Economy 60% $240 million New Project Opportunity: Zen can invest $60 million today in new routing optimization software. One year from today, this project will be worth: State Probability Project Value Weak Economy 40% $50 million Strong Economy 60% $90 million Assumptions: ●​ Required return for all assets and projects: 10% ●​ Zen currently has no cash and no debt A) Value existing assets today (10 pts) Calculate the current market value of Zen's existing assets (before any project decision). Expected asset value one year from now: E[Asset Value] = ? Present value today: V_Assets = E[Asset Value] / (1 + r) = ? B) Compute project NPV ignoring financing (10 pts) In an M&M world with no financing frictions, calculate the project's NPV. Expected project value one year from now: E[Project Value] = ? Present value today: PV_Project = ? NPV: NPV = PV_Project - $60M investment = ? Is this a value-creating project? C) All-debt financing scenario (15 pts) Zen has no cash, so it must raise external financing. The company decides to finance the entire $60 million project by issuing debt. Debt structure: ●​ One-year zero-coupon bond ●​ Face value: $60 million ●​ Assume the debt is truly risk-free (no default in either state) Calculate: 1.​ New firm value (existing assets + project): ○​ In weak economy: Total assets = ? ○​ In strong economy: Total assets = ? ○​ Expected total asset value = ? ○​ PV of total firm today = ? 2.​ Debt value today: Since the debt is risk-free and pays $60M in one year: ○​ V_Debt = $60M / (1.10) = ? 3.​ Wait - if the debt is truly risk-free, should we discount at 10%? Reconsider: if risk-free, discount at risk-free rate. But the problem says required return for all assets is 10%, which suggests we should use 10% or clarify. For this problem, assume we use 10% as stated, but note this creates an arbitrage if the debt is truly risk-free. 4.​ Equity value today: ○​ V_Equity = V_Firm - V_Debt = ? D) Wealth comparison for existing shareholders (15 pts) Before the debt-financed project: ●​ Total equity value = V_Assets (from part A) ●​ Value per share = V_Assets / 8M shares ●​ Existing shareholders own 100% of equity After the debt-financed project: ●​ Total equity value = V_Firm - V_Debt (from part C) ●​ Existing shareholders still own 100% of equity (no equity dilution with debt financing) ●​ Value per share = New V_Equity / 8M shares Calculate: Scenario Equity Value Chan ge Before (no project) After (debt-financed project) Net change Are existing shareholders better or worse off? Explain: ●​ How much of the project's NPV do they capture? ●​ Why is all-debt financing attractive when there's no equity dilution? E) Risky debt and risk-shifting incentives (30 pts) Now suppose the debt is risky rather than risk-free. Specifically: ●​ Face value still $60 million ●​ In the weak economy (assets = $160M + $50M = $210M), debt is easily repaid ●​ But default becomes possible if Zen subsequently takes on additional risks Analyze qualitatively: Part 1 - Shareholder wealth with risky debt (10 pts): If default becomes possible in some scenarios: 1.​ How does the debt value change? ○​ Would risky debt trade at less than the risk-free value? ○​ Why? 2.​ How does equity value change? ○​ If V_Firm is unchanged but V_Debt decreases, what happens to V_Equity? ○​ Do shareholders benefit from the debt being risky? Part 2 - Value of the project to shareholders (10 pts): Suppose the project primarily benefits the weak state (improving outcomes when times are bad): 1.​ Who benefits most from projects that improve bad-state outcomes? ○​ Debt holders (who care about downside protection)? ○​ Equity holders (who care about upside)? 2.​ Could shareholders actually capture less than the full project NPV? ○​ If the project reduces default risk, who captures that value? Part 3 - Risk-shifting incentives (10 pts): With risky debt outstanding, explain: 1.​ What is risk-shifting? ○​ Why might shareholders favor risky projects even with negative NPV? ○​ How does leverage make equity behave like an option? 2.​ How does this affect project choice? ○​ Might shareholders reject the safe, positive-NPV routing software? ○​ Might they prefer a risky, negative-NPV speculative venture instead? ○​ How does the option-like nature of equity explain this? 3.​ Debt covenants: ○​ How could debt covenants restrict risk-shifting? ○​ Give one specific example of a covenant that would help

solution.content:
Question 2 – Short Conceptual Questions (40 points)
A) Positive Alpha and Market Efficiency (15 pts)
TechGrowth Inc. is a publicly traded technology company. An analyst runs a CAPM regression on the stock's historical returns and estimates:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Beta = 1.1
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Risk-free rate = 4%
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Market risk premium = 6%
CAPM prediction: Expected return = 4% + 1.1 × 6% = 10.6%
However, TechGrowth's long-run realized average return has been 13.6%, implying an alpha of +3.0%.
Answer the following:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. What does positive alpha mean in CAPM terms?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Define alpha formally
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Explain what it means for a stock to deliver returns above its CAPM prediction
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Interpretation 1 - True Mispricing: If markets are inefficient, what does this positive alpha suggest?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Is the stock undervalued or overvalued?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * What trading strategy would exploit this?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Why might the mispricing persist?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Interpretation 2 - Measurement Issues: If markets are efficient, what might explain the apparent alpha?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Sampling error / luck over the estimation period?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Risk factors not captured by the single-factor CAPM (e.g., size, value, momentum)?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Errors in measuring beta?
Discuss: How should a rational investor interpret this positive alpha? What additional analysis would help distinguish between these interpretations?
B) Debt vs. Equity Financing Under Trade-Off Theory (15 pts)
Reliable Industries has a strong balance sheet, stable cash flows, and very low current leverage (D/E = 0.1). The company has identified a positive-NPV expansion project requiring $100 million in financing.
Financing options:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * All equity: Issue $100M in new common stock
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * All debt: Issue $100M in bonds
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Mixed: Some combination
Under trade-off theory, analyze the financing decision:
Part 1 - Why some debt might be preferred to all equity:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. What is the tax advantage of debt?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * If the corporate tax rate is 25% and the debt coupon rate is 6%, calculate the annual tax shield from $100M of debt
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * How does this tax shield benefit shareholders?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. Why is the expected cost of financial distress likely low for Reliable Industries?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Current low leverage
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Stable cash flows
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Strong balance sheet
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Conclusion: Why does trade-off theory suggest that some debt is optimal?
Part 2 - Why all debt could be suboptimal:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. What happens to distress costs as leverage increases?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Probability of distress
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Expected magnitude of distress costs
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       2. At some leverage level, what relationship holds at the optimum?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Marginal benefit of tax shields
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Marginal cost of expected distress
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       3. Conclusion: Why might 100% debt financing exceed the optimal leverage ratio?
Overall answer: Explain why the trade-off theory predicts an interior optimum (some debt, but not all debt).
C) Fixed vs. Floating Rate Debt (10 pts)
Companies can choose between:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Fixed-rate debt: Interest rate locked in (e.g., 6% for 5 years)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Floating-rate debt: Interest rate adjusts with market rates (e.g., LIBOR + 2%)
Scenario 1 - Highly cyclical firm (e.g., automotive manufacturer):
This firm's cash flows are:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * High during economic booms
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Low during recessions
Interest rates tend to be:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * High during booms (Fed tightens)
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Low during recessions (Fed eases)
Explain:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Why might this firm prefer fixed-rate debt?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * How does floating-rate debt create additional risk?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * When would interest payments be highest?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * When would cash flows be lowest?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Why does this correlation increase distress risk?
Scenario 2 - Very stable firm (e.g., regulated utility):
This firm has:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Predictable cash flows
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Low correlation with economic cycles
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Minimal distress risk
Explain:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Why might this firm be more willing to use floating-rate debt?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * Is the mismatch between rates and cash flows a major concern?
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       * What are potential benefits of floating-rate debt (e.g., typically lower initial rates, flexibility)?
Conclude: How should the relationship between a firm's cash flows and interest rate cycles influence the fixed vs. floating decision?
________________

solution.content:
Question 2 – Short Conceptual Questions (40 points)
Answer each part briefly but completely. Use course concepts and clear economic reasoning.
________________


A. Risk-Shifting and Debt Maturity (15 pts)
Apex Manufacturing has £800m of short-term bank debt due in one year. The CFO is considering refinancing this into £800m of 10-year bonds with similar credit terms.
Explain how moving from mostly short-term debt to mostly long-term debt affects:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 1. Equity’s incentives to take very risky projects (“gambling for resurrection”).
 How does the timing of debt maturity change the extent to which equity captures upside vs bears downside on risky bets?

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 2. Expected costs of financial distress.
 Discuss how debt maturity influences both:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * The probability of distress, and

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    * The severity of distress costs (direct and indirect).

________________


B. Beta of Debt vs Beta of Equity (15 pts)
Consider a levered firm with risky debt and positive asset beta ( \beta_A > 0 ).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       1. Explain why the equity beta ( \beta_E ) is generally higher than the asset beta. Your answer should reference:

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * The relationship
[
\beta_A = \frac{D}{D+E}\beta_D + \frac{E}{D+E}\beta_E
]

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * Financial leverage and residual claims, and

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          * How equity absorbs amplified swings in asset value.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             2. Under what conditions can the debt beta ( \beta_D ) be close to zero, even if ( \beta_A ) is large?
Discuss at least two factors (e.g., leverage level, seniority/collateral, maturity) and explain when debt is “bond-like” vs “equity-like”.

________________


C. Pension Liabilities as Hidden Debt (10 pts)
Steelworx Industries has £500m of unfunded defined-benefit pension obligations and £100m of financial debt (bonds).
From a capital structure and distress-risk perspective, explain why pension liabilities can be viewed as “hidden debt.” In your answer, address:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * How pension obligations resemble fixed claims like interest and principal on bonds.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Where pension claims typically sit in priority relative to financial creditors.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * How this should affect Steelworx’s view of its true leverage and optimal additional financial debt.

________________

worked_examples.title: Capital Structure and Leasing
worked_examples.problem_statement: TangoAir is evaluating whether to buy or lease a new aircraft. Buy Option ●​ Purchase price today (t = 0): $200m​ ●​ Useful life: 20 years​ ●​ Depreciation: Straight-line to zero ($10m per year)​ ●​ Maintenance capex: 30% of depreciation ($3m per year)​ ●​ No salvage value at t = 20​ ●​ Corporate tax rate: 25%​ ●​ Discount rate: 9%​ Lease Option ●​ 20-year operating lease​ ●​ Annual lease payment: $18m (paid at year-end)​ ●​ Lease payments are fully tax-deductible operating expenses​ ●​ Assume old GAAP: lease is not capitalized on TangoAir’s balance sheet​ Ignore how the buy option is financed (focus on operating/tax cash flows only).

worked_examples.title: EPS, Leverage, and Illusions
worked_examples.problem_statement: A firm currently has: ●​ EBIT: $100m​ ●​ No debt​ ●​ Shares outstanding: 50m​ ●​ Current stock price: $40 per share​ ●​ Corporate tax rate: 25%​ The firm is considering issuing $200m of debt at 6%, and using the proceeds to repurchase shares at the current price. A. Current EPS (5 pts) Compute current EPS (before leverage): [​ \text{EPS}_0 = \frac{\text{Net income}}{\text{Shares}}.​ ] ●​ Net income = EBIT × (1 − tax rate).​ ●​ Shares = 50m.​ Show the numerical value.

solution.content:
Question 2 – Conceptual Cluster (40 points)
A. Utilities vs Tech Capital Structure (15 pts)
Compare the typical leverage of regulated utilities vs high-growth technology firms, and explain why utilities tend to carry much more debt. In your answer, discuss at least three of the following:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Cash flow risk and predictability

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Growth opportunities and debt overhang

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Asset tangibility and collateral value

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Indirect financial distress costs

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             * Tax position and use of loss carryforwards

Conclude with a brief statement on how these factors jointly explain the observed differences.
________________


B. Debt Overhang – Numeric Example (15 pts)
Define debt overhang and illustrate it with a simple numeric example.
Construct a 2- or 3-state example where:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * The firm has risky debt outstanding.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * A new project has positive NPV for the firm as a whole.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Equity must supply the investment cost.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                * Equity’s value falls or barely rises if the project is undertaken, so equity rationally rejects it.

Show payoffs to debt and equity with and without the project, compute firm and equity NPVs, and briefly explain why equity refuses to invest and who captures the project’s value.
________________


C. MM with Corporate Taxes Only (10 pts)
Under Modigliani–Miller with corporate taxes only, firm value satisfies
( V_L = V_U + \tau_C D ).
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   1. State the model’s extreme prediction for optimal capital structure and the key assumptions that lead to this result.

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   2. Briefly discuss three important real-world frictions that overturn the “100% debt” prediction (e.g., distress costs, underinvestment/debt overhang, agency problems and risk-shifting).

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   3. Explain in a sentence or two how the trade-off theory modifies MM and leads to an interior optimal leverage rather than 100% debt.

________________

solution.content:
Question 2 – Short Conceptual Questions (40 points)
Answer each part briefly but completely.
________________


A. Zero-coupon vs coupon debt risk (15 pts)
In 4-5 sentences, explain why zero-coupon debt can be riskier than coupon-paying debt with the same face value and maturity.
Your answer should address:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Duration and interest rate sensitivity
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Concentration of payment at maturity
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Refinancing risk if the firm needs to roll over debt
________________


B. Maturity and debt beta (15 pts)
In 3-4 sentences, explain how debt maturity affects debt beta (β_D), holding everything else constant.
Discuss:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Whether longer maturity makes debt more or less equity-like
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * How time-to-maturity affects the option value of limited liability
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Which has higher β: 1-year debt or 10-year debt on the same firm?
________________


C. Why mix debt maturities? (10 pts)
In 3-4 sentences, explain why firms often choose a mix of short-term and long-term debt instead of concentrating all borrowing at one maturity.
Consider:
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Refinancing risk vs rollover flexibility
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Matching asset duration
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        * Market timing and yield curve considerations
________________

worked_examples.title: Fixed vs Floating Debt Mix
worked_examples.problem_statement: Firm I has $400m of total debt: Debt Structure: ●​ $200m fixed-rate debt at 6% (10 years remaining) ●​ $200m floating-rate debt at LIBOR + 2% (10 years remaining) ○​ Current LIBOR: 3%, so current floating rate = 5% Market Expectations: ●​ LIBOR expected to average 4% over the next 10 years ●​ But with wide swings: could range from 1% to 7% Corporate tax rate: 25%

Effect on equity beta (15 pts)
Cyclical vs stable firms (15 pts)
Risk management vs market speculation (15 pts)
Three hedging concepts (15 pts)
"We think prices will move in our favor" (10 pts)
USD revenue and profit by state (15 pts)
Natural hedge: Euro sourcing (20 pts)
Forward contract overlay (25 pts)

Replicating a protective put (15 pts)
Why synthetic positions matter for corporate finance (15 pts)
Corporate contract as an option (15 pts)
